headlines.headline: Unseen footage of the London Bridge attacks

items.summary: The BBC has obtained footage of the night which shows unarmed police and members of the public as they tried to confront the armed men.

media.title: Unseen footage of the London Bridge attacks

synopses.short: Unseen footage of the London Bridge attacks
synopses.long:
For the first time, the BBC can show footage of the moment unarmed officers and members of the public came face to face with the three London Bridge attackers.
The footage was filmed by Paul Clarke, a member of the public who was at the scene of the attack on the night. 
This video was shown at both the inquest into the victims' deaths and the inquest into the attackers' deaths which concluded that the three attackers were lawfully killed by the police. 
Khuram Butt, Rachid Redouane, and Youssef Zaghba ploughed into pedestrians on the bridge before stabbing people at Borough Market. They killed eight people before they were shot dead by firearms officers.
synopses.medium: The BBC has obtained footage of the night which shows unarmed police and members of the public as they tried to confront the armed men.

media.caption: BBC correspondent Daniel Sandford on the unseen footage of the London Bridge attacks

warnings.long: Contains scenes which some viewers may find disturbing.

items.overtypedSummary: Footage of the night shows unarmed police and members of the public try to confront the armed men.

headlines.headline: MEPs elect first female EU Commission president

items.summary: German Ursula von der Leyen will replace Jean-Claude Juncker on 1 November after a close vote.

media.title: EU's first female president thanks MEPs after vote

synopses.short: Ursula von der Leyen 'honoured' to be elected president
synopses.long:
Germany's Ursula von der Leyen has been narrowly elected president of the EU Commission following a secret ballot among MEPs.

The centre-right defence minister will replace Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker on 1 November.
synopses.medium: Germany's Ursula von der Leyen is voted in by MEPs as the head of the EU Commission.

media.caption: Ursula von der Leyen: "The endeavour is a united, strong Europe"

headlines.headline: I am not a racist, insists Trump

items.summary: The US president hits back after his controversial attack on four minority Democratic congresswomen.

media.title: Congresswomen hit back in Trump race row

synopses.short: Congresswomen hit back in Trump race row
synopses.long:
Four congresswomen attacked by President Trump in a series of tweets have dismissed dismissed his defence of them.
Ayanna Pressley, Ilhan Omar, Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and Rashida Tlaib said the tweets were racist and a distraction from their criticism of the president's border control policy.
synopses.medium: Four congresswomen dismiss the US president's defence of his controversial tweets.

media.caption: Ayanna Pressley, Ilhan Omar, Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and Rashida Tlaib responded to the attacks at a press conference on Monday

headlines.headline: How doctors separate twins joined at the head

items.summary: Exclusive access to Great Ormond Street as surgeons worked to separate two girls who shared a skull.

media.title: How doctors separate twins joined at the head

synopses.short: Conjoined twins: how doctors separated twins joined at the head
synopses.long:
Safa and Marwa were born joined at the skull, they've never been able to see each other's faces.
There are no official figures for how often this happens, but one estimate says craniopagus conjoined twins are born once in every 2.5 million births. 
Most do not live longer than a day.
To separate them required multiple surgeries, months of hard work and the expertise of hundreds of hospital workers.
The BBC was given exclusive access to Great Ormond Street as surgeons worked to separate the two girls.
Video by Laura Foster
synopses.medium: Exclusive access to Great Ormond Street as surgeons worked to separate two girls who shared a skull.

media.caption: The battle to separate Safa and Marwa

headlines.headline: Inside Iran: Are Tehran's poor paying the price?

items.summary: US imposed sanctions are crippling the economy, making food and medicines unaffordable.

media.title: Inside Iran: Are Tehran's poor paying the price?

synopses.short: Inside Iran: Are Tehran's poorest paying the price?
synopses.long:
Donald Trump withdrew from the Iran nuclear deal in 2018 and has imposed ever tightening sanctions on the country in a move designed to force Tehran to curtail their nuclear ambitions. 

The sanctions have led to increased prices and the local currency has fallen significantly. Iranians are being dragged into poverty and the poorest are feeling the effects.

As tensions rise between Iran, the United States and its allies, the BBC has been given rare access to Iran.

BBC Middle East correspondent Martin Patience, has been in Tehran looking at the impact of sanctions. While in the country, filming access was controlled - as with all foreign media the team was accompanied by a government representative at all times.
synopses.medium: US imposed sanctions are crippling the economy, making food and medicines unaffordable.

media.caption: Tehran's poorest hit by US sanctions

headlines.headline: 'Hearing my new voice for the first time'

items.summary: When Rose Brown was aged 12, she was hit by a drink driver and left unable to walk or talk. She's now been able to choose how she sounds.

media.title: 'Choosing my new voice'

synopses.short: 'Choosing the woman who be my new voice'
synopses.long:
When Rose Brown was aged 12, she was hit by a drink driver and left unable to walk or talk.

Now aged 20, she has been given the opportunity to create a bespoke digital voice to transform her ability to communicate. 

Reporter Claire Jones has been to meet her.

headlines.headline: Inside the former US Embassy in Iran

items.summary: The BBC has been given rare access inside the country as tensions with the United States and its allies increase.

media.title: Inside the former US Embassy in Iran

synopses.short: Inside the former US Embassy in Iran
synopses.long:
The BBC has been given rare access in Iran at a key time. Iranians remain angry that Donald Trump pulled out of the nuclear deal in 2018 and has imposed crushing sanctions on the country.

BBC Middle East correspondent Martin Patience, along with Cameraman Nik Millard and Producer Cara Swift were given a tour of the former US Embassy by the former Deputy Foreign Minister Hossein Sheikholeslam – talking to him about the escalating crisis.

There were some restrictions on the team’s movements but not on what they are saying. As with all foreign media, the team was accompanied by a government representative at all times.
synopses.medium: The BBC has been given rare access inside the country as tensions increase with the United States and its allies.

media.caption: Inside the former US Embassy in Iran

indexImage.altText: Communications equipment in former US embassy in Iran

headlines.headline: Making memories instead of buying new toys
headlines.overtyped: Making memories instead of buying new toys

items.summary: Nicola is doing a 'no buy' year and fighting back against social media pressure to buy new things.

media.title: No Buy Year: Making new memories instead of buying new toys

synopses.short: No Buy Year: 'They won't remember the toys, they'll remember the time we spent together'
synopses.long: Nicola is a music teacher and blogger from Darlington. She lives with her husband and two children - Alfie and Charlie.She has had to overcome a major online shopping habit which she says was fuelled by Instagram pages showing families giving their kids the ‘perfect’ life. She’s now committed to buying her kids no new toys or new clothing in 2019. Instead she wants to create memories which she hopes will be worth more than the latest toy or gadget when they’re older.
synopses.medium: Nicola is doing a 'no buy' year and fighting back against social media pressure to buy new things.

media.caption: No Buy Year: 'They won't remember the toys, they'll remember the time we spent together'

headlines.headline: How did the US put the first men on the Moon?

items.summary: It's 50 years since the first ever manned landing on the Moon - what was involved?

headlines.headline: The only woman in the Apollo 11 control room

items.summary: JoAnn Morgan tells the BBC about her role at the launch of the Apollo 11 mission to the Moon.

media.title: The only woman in the Apollo 11 control room

synopses.short: Apollo 11: 'They'd never had a woman engineer'
synopses.long:
At 28-years-old, Joann Morgan was the only woman in the control room for the launch of Apollo 11 mission to the Moon, 50 years ago.

Morgan was an engineer responsible for 21 channels of communications and the health and welfare of all the monitoring systems for the Saturn 5 rocket which launched the Apollo spacecraft into space. 

She told BBC Today programme presenter Mishal Husain about the experience.
synopses.medium: JoAnn Morgan tells the BBC about her role in the control room at the Apollo 11 launch.

media.caption: Apollo 11's Joann Morgan: 'They'd never had a woman engineer'

items.summary: Fifty years on, here are four things that made the Apollo Moon programme one of humankind's greatest technological achievements.

headlines.headline: 'My dad literally loved us to the Moon and back'

items.summary: All the focus was on the Moon, the mission and the men – but what about the families back on Earth?

media.title: 'My dad literally loved us to the Moon and back'

synopses.short: Apollo landing: 'My dad literally loved us to the Moon and back'
synopses.long:
All the focus was on the Moon, the mission and the men - but what about the families back on Earth? 

The BBC asked Sue and Amy Bean, the wife and daughter, respectively, of astronaut Alan Beal, the fourth man on the Moon.

Video by Angelica M Casas and Samantha Granville
